rdfs:label: Background-activity
dc:description: An EEG activity representing the setting in which a given normal or abnormal pattern appears and from which such pattern is distinguished.

rdfs:label: Posterior-dominant-rhythm
Attributes: suggestedTag=Feature-significance-to-recording, suggestedTag=Feature-frequency, suggestedTag=Posterior-dominant-rhythm-property, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S2, annotation=dc:source suggested tags from Beniczky ea 2017 Table 4.
dc:description: Rhythmic activity occurring during wakefulness over the posterior regions of the head, generally with maximum amplitudes over the occipital areas. Amplitude varies. Best seen with eyes closed and during physical relaxation and relative mental inactivity. Blocked or attenuated by attention, especially visual, and mental effort. In adults this is the alpha rhythm, and the frequency is 8 to 13 Hz. However the frequency can be higher or lower than this range (often a supra or sub harmonic of alpha frequency) and is called alpha variant rhythm (fast and slow alpha variant rhythm). In children, the normal range of the frequency of the posterior dominant rhythm is age-dependant.

rdfs:label: Mu-rhythm
Attributes: suggestedTag=Feature-frequency, suggestedTag=Feature-significance-to-recording, suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Sensor-list, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S2.
dc:description: EEG rhythm at 7-11 Hz composed of arch-shaped waves occurring over the central or centro-parietal regions of the scalp during wakefulness. Amplitudes varies but is mostly below 50 microV. Blocked or attenuated most clearly by contralateral movement, thought of movement, readiness to move or tactile stimulation.

rdfs:label: Other-organized-rhythm
Attributes: requireChild, suggestedTag=Rhythmic-property, suggestedTag=Feature-significance-to-recording, suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Sensor-list, suggestedTag=Appearance-mode, suggestedTag=Discharge-pattern, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S2.
dc:description: EEG activity consisting of waves of approximately constant period that are considered part of the background (ongoing) activity, but do not fulfill the criteria of the posterior dominant rhythm.

rdfs:label: Background-burst-suppression
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Sensor-list, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S2, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Section 6.

rdfs:label: Background-burst-attenuation
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Sensor-list, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Section 6.

rdfs:label: Background-activity-suppression
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Sensor-list, suggestedTag=Appearance-mode, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S2, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Section 6.

rdfs:label: Electrocerebral-inactivity
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S2, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Section 6.
dc:description: Absence of any ongoing cortical electric activities; in all leads EEG is isoelectric or only contains artifacts. Sensitivity has to be increased up to 2 microV/mm; recording time: at least 30 minutes.

rdfs:label: Critically-ill-patient-patterns
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Hirsch ea 2013, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Section 9.
dc:description: Rhythmic or periodic patterns in critically ill patients (RPPs) are scored according to the 2012 version of the American Clinical Neurophysiology Society Standardized Critical Care EEG Terminology.

rdfs:label: Critically-ill-patient-periodic-discharges
Attributes: suggestedTag=RPP-morphology, suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Sensor-list, suggestedTag=Feature-frequency, suggestedTag=RPP-time-related-feature, annotation=dc:source Hirsch ea 2013, annotation=dc:source Suggested tags from Beniczky ea 2017 Table 8.
dc:description: Periodic discharges (PDs): Periodic - repetition of a waveform with relatively uniform morphology and duration with a quantifiable inter-discharge interval between consecutive waveforms and recurrence of the waveform at nearly regular intervals.

rdfs:label: Rhythmic-delta-activity
Attributes: suggestedTag=RPP-with-superimposed-activity, suggestedTag=RPP-absolute-amplitude, suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Sensor-list, suggestedTag=Feature-frequency, suggestedTag=RPP-time-related-feature, annotation=dc:source Hirsch ea 2013, annotation=dc:source Suggested tags from Beniczky ea 2017 Table 8.
dc:description: Rhythmic Delta Activity (RDA): Rhythmic - repetition of a waveform with relatively uniform morphology and duration, and without an interval between consecutive waveforms. RDA - rhythmic activity less than or equal to 4 Hz. The duration of one cycle (i.e., the period) of the rhythmic pattern should vary by less than 50 percent from the duration of the subsequent cycle for the majority (greater than 50 percent) of cycle pairs to qualify as rhythmic.

rdfs:label: Spike-or-sharp-and-wave
Attributes: suggestedTag=RPP-sharpness, suggestedTag=Number-of-RPP-phases, suggestedTag=Triphasic-morphology, suggestedTag=RPP-absolute-amplitude, suggestedTag=RPP-relative-amplitude, suggestedTag=RPP-polarity, suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Sensor-list, suggestedTag=Multifocal-feature, suggestedTag=Feature-frequency, suggestedTag=RPP-time-related-feature, annotation=dc:source Hirsch ea 2013, annotation=dc:source Suggested tags from Beniczky ea 2017 Table 8.
dc:description: Spike-and-wave or Sharp-and-wave (SW) - polyspike, spike or sharp wave consistently followed by a slow wave in a regularly repeating and alternating pattern (spike-wave-spike-wave-spike-wave), with a consistent relationship between the spike (or polyspike or sharp wave) component and the slow wave; and with no interval between one spike-wave complex and the next (if there is an interval, this would qualify as PDs, where each discharge is a spike-and- wave).

rdfs:label: Episode
dc:description: Clinical episode or electrographic seizure.

rdfs:label: Epileptic-seizure
Attributes: suggestedTag=Episode-consciousness-affected, suggestedTag=Episode-awareness, suggestedTag=Episode-prodrome, suggestedTag=Episode-tongue-biting, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 9 Supplement 1, annotation=dc:source Selection-tree and list of seizure-types according to the current ILAE seizure classification Fisher ea 2017.
dc:description: The ILAE seizure classification divides seizures into focal, generalized onset, or unknown onset.

rdfs:label: Focal-onset-epileptic-seizure
Attributes: suggestedTag=Automatism-seizure, suggestedTag=Atonic-seizure, suggestedTag=Clonic-seizure, suggestedTag=Epileptic-spasm, suggestedTag=Hyperkinetic-seizure, suggestedTag=Myoclonic-seizure, suggestedTag=Tonic-seizure, suggestedTag=Autonomic-seizure, suggestedTag=Behavior-arrest-seizure, suggestedTag=Cognitive-seizure, suggestedTag=Emotional-seizure, suggestedTag=Sensory-seizure, annotation=dc:source Fisher ea 2017 Table 2 and Key Points, annotation=dc:source Suggested tags from Fisher ea 2017 Figure 2, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Supplement 1, annotation=dc:source ILAE seizure classification code I.
dc:description: A focal seizure originates within networks limited to one hemisphere. They may be discretely localized or more widely distributed. Focal seizures may originate in subcortical structures. Focal seizures are optionally subdivided into focal aware and focal impaired awareness seizures. Specific motor and nonmotor classifiers may be added.

rdfs:label: Aware-focal-onset-epileptic-seizure
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Fisher ea 2017 Table 2 and Key Points, annotation=dc:source Suggested tags from Fisher ea 2017 Figure 2, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Supplement 1, annotation=dc:source ILAE seizure classification code I.
dc:description: Focal onset and maintained awareness (knowledge of self or environment).

rdfs:label: Impaired-awareness-focal-onset-epileptic-seizure
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Fisher ea 2017 Table 2, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Supplement 1, annotation=dc:source ILAE seizure classification code I.B.
dc:description: Focal onset and impaired or lost awareness (knowledge of self or environment) is a feature of focal impaired awareness seizures, previously called complex partial seizures.

rdfs:label: Awareness-unknown-focal-onset-epileptic-seizure
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Fisher ea 2017 Table 2, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Supplement 1, annotation=dc:source ILAE seizure classification code I.C.
dc:description: Focal onset and awareness (knowledge of self or environment) unknown or not specified.

rdfs:label: Focal-to-bilateral-tonic-clonic-focal-onset-epileptic-seizure
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Fisher ea 2017 Table 2, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Supplement 1, annotation=dc:source ILAE seizure classification code I.D.01.
dc:description: A seizure type with focal onset, with awareness or impaired awareness, either motor or non-motor, progressing to bilateral tonic clonic activity. The prior term was seizure with partial onset with secondary generalization.

rdfs:label: Generalized-onset-epileptic-seizure
Attributes: suggestedTag=Tonic-clonic-seizure, suggestedTag=Clonic-seizure, suggestedTag=Tonic-seizure, suggestedTag=Myoclonic-seizure, suggestedTag=Myoclonic-tonic-clonic-seizure, suggestedTag=Myoclonic-atonic-seizure, suggestedTag=Atonic-seizure, suggestedTag=Epileptic-spasm, suggestedTag=Typical-absence-seizure, suggestedTag=Atypical-absence-seizure, suggestedTag=Myoclonic-absence-seizure, suggestedTag=Eyelid-myoclonia-seizure, annotation=dc:source Fisher ea 2017 Table 2 and Key Points, annotation=dc:source Suggested tags from Fisher ea 2017 Figure 2, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Supplement 1, annotation=dc:source ILAE seizure classification code II.
dc:description: Generalized seizures originate at some point within, and rapidly engaging, bilaterally distributed networks. Generalized onset seizures can be motor: tonic clonic, clonic, tonic, myoclonic, myoclonic tonic clonic, myoclonic atonic, atonic, and epileptic spasms. Generalized onset seizures can also be nonmotor (absence): typical absence, atypical absence, myoclonic absence, or absence with eyelid myoclonia.

rdfs:label: Unknown-onset-epileptic-seizure
Attributes: suggestedTag=Tonic-clonic-seizure, suggestedTag=Epileptic-spasm, suggestedTag=Behavior-arrest-seizure, annotation=dc:source Fisher ea 2017 page 532, annotation=dc:source Suggested tags from Fisher ea 2017 Figure 2, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Supplement 1, annotation=dc:source ILAE seizure classification code III.
dc:description: A seizure of unknown onset may still evidence certain defining motor (e.g., tonic clonic) or nonmotor (e.g., behavior arrest) characteristics. With further information or future observed seizures, a reclassification of unknown-onset seizures into focal or generalized-onset categories may become possible. Therefore, unknown onset is not a characteristic of the seizure, but a convenient placeholder for our ignorance.

rdfs:label: Unclassified-epileptic-seizure
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Fisher ea 2017 Table 2, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Supplement 1, annotation=dc:source ILAE seizure classification code III.C.01.
dc:description: Referring to a seizure type that cannot be described by the ILAE 2017 classification either because of inadequate information or unusual clinical features.

rdfs:label: Electroencephalographic-seizure
Attributes: suggestedTag=Episode-consciousness-affected, suggestedTag=Episode-awareness, suggestedTag=Episode-prodrome, suggestedTag=Episode-tongue-biting, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 9.
dc:description: Refers usually to non convulsive status. Ictal EEG: rhythmic discharge or spike and wave pattern with definite evolution in frequency, location, or morphology lasting at least 10 s; evolution in amplitude alone did not qualify.

rdfs:label: Seizure-PNES
Attributes: suggestedTag=Feature-significance-to-recording, suggestedTag=Episode-consciousness-affected, suggestedTag=Episode-awareness, suggestedTag=Episode-prodrome, suggestedTag=Episode-tongue-biting, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 9.
dc:description: Psychogenic non-epileptic seizure. Paroxysmal events that mimic (or are confused with) epileptic seizures, but which do not result from epileptic activity; they lack the EEG ictal features during the ictus.

rdfs:label: Sleep-related-episode
Attributes: suggestedTag=Feature-significance-to-recording, suggestedTag=Episode-consciousness-affected, suggestedTag=Episode-awareness, suggestedTag=Episode-prodrome, suggestedTag=Episode-tongue-biting, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 9.

rdfs:label: Sleep-related-arousal
dc:description: Normal arousal.

rdfs:label: Benign-sleep-myoclonus
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 9, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5.
dc:description: A distinctive disorder of sleep characterized by a) neonatal onset, b) rhythmic myoclonic jerks only during sleep and c) abrupt and consistent cessation with arousal, d) absence of concomitant electrographic changes suggestive of seizures, and e) good outcome.

rdfs:label: Confusional-arousal
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 9, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5.
dc:description: Episode of non epileptic nature included in NREM parasomnias, characterized by sudden arousal and complex behavior but without full alertness, usually lasting a few minutes and occurring almost in all children at least occasionally. Amnesia of the episode is the rule.

rdfs:label: Cataplexy
Attributes: suggestedTag=Feature-significance-to-recording, suggestedTag=Episode-consciousness-affected, suggestedTag=Episode-awareness, suggestedTag=Episode-prodrome, suggestedTag=Episode-tongue-biting, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 9, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5.
dc:description: A sudden decrement in muscle tone and loss of deep tendon reflexes, leading to muscle weakness, paralysis, or postural collapse. Cataplexy usually is precipitated by an outburst of emotional expression-notably laughter, anger, or startle. It is one of the tetrad of symptoms of narcolepsy. During cataplexy, respiration and voluntary eye movements are not compromised. Consciousness is preserved.

rdfs:label: Sleep-periodic-limb-movement
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 9, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: PLMS (Periodic limb movement in sleep). Episodes are characterized by brief (0.5- to 5.0-second) lower-extremity movements during sleep, which typically occur at 20- to 40-second intervals, most commonly during the first 3 hours of sleep. The affected individual is usually not aware of the movements or of the transient partial arousals.

rdfs:label: REM-sleep-behavioral-disorder
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 9, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5.
dc:description: REM sleep behavioral disorder. Episodes characterized by: a) presence of REM sleep without atonia (RSWA) on polysomnography (PSG); b) presence of at least 1 of the following conditions - (1) Sleep-related behaviors, by history, that have been injurious, potentially injurious, or disruptive (example: dream enactment behavior); (2) abnormal REM sleep behavior documented during PSG monitoring; (3) absence of epileptiform activity on electroencephalogram (EEG) during REM sleep (unless RBD can be clearly distinguished from any concurrent REM sleep-related seizure disorder); (4) sleep disorder not better explained by another sleep disorder, a medical or neurologic disorder, a mental disorder, medication use, or a substance use disorder.

rdfs:label: Sleep-walking
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 9, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Episodes characterized by ambulation during sleep; the patient is difficult to arouse during an episode, and is usually amnesic following the episode. Episodes usually occur in the first third of the night during slow wave sleep. Polysomnographic recordings demonstrate 2 abnormalities during the first sleep cycle: frequent, brief, non-behavioral EEG-defined arousals prior to the somnambulistic episode and abnormally low gamma (0.75-2.0 Hz) EEG power on spectral analysis, correlating with high-voltage (hyper-synchronic gamma) waves lasting 10 to 15 s occurring just prior to the movement. This is followed by stage I NREM sleep, and there is no evidence of complete awakening.

rdfs:label: Pediatric-episode
Attributes: suggestedTag=Feature-significance-to-recording, suggestedTag=Episode-consciousness-affected, suggestedTag=Episode-awareness, suggestedTag=Episode-prodrome, suggestedTag=Episode-tongue-biting, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 9.

rdfs:label: Hyperekplexia
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 9, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Disorder characterized by exaggerated startle response and hypertonicity that may occur during the first year of life and in severe cases during the neonatal period. Children usually present with marked irritability and recurrent startles in response to handling and sounds. Severely affected infants can have severe jerks and stiffening, sometimes with breath-holding spells.

rdfs:label: Jactatio-capitis-nocturna
dc:description: Relatively common in normal children at the time of going to bed, especially during the first year of life, the rhythmic head movements persist during sleep. Usually, these phenomena disappear before 3 years of age.

rdfs:label: Pavor-nocturnus
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 9, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: A nocturnal episode characterized by age of onset of less than five years (mean age 18 months, with peak prevalence at five to seven years), appearance of signs of panic two hours after falling asleep with crying, screams, a fearful expression, inability to recognize other people including parents (for a duration of 5-15 minutes), amnesia upon awakening. Pavor nocturnus occurs in patients almost every night for months or years (but the frequency is highly variable and may be as low as once a month) and is likely to disappear spontaneously at the age of six to eight years.

rdfs:label: Pediatric-stereotypical-behavior-episode
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 9, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Repetitive motor behavior in children, typically rhythmic and persistent; usually not paroxysmal and rarely suggest epilepsy. They include headbanging, head-rolling, jactatio capitis nocturna, body rocking, buccal or lingual movements, hand flapping and related mannerisms, repetitive hand-waving (to self-induce photosensitive seizures).

rdfs:label: Paroxysmal-motor-event
Attributes: suggestedTag=Feature-significance-to-recording, suggestedTag=Episode-consciousness-affected, suggestedTag=Episode-awareness, suggestedTag=Episode-prodrome, suggestedTag=Episode-tongue-biting, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 9, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Paroxysmal phenomena during neonatal or childhood periods characterized by recurrent motor or behavioral signs or symptoms that must be distinguished from epileptic disorders.

rdfs:label: Syncope
Attributes: suggestedTag=Feature-significance-to-recording, suggestedTag=Episode-consciousness-affected, suggestedTag=Episode-awareness, suggestedTag=Episode-prodrome, suggestedTag=Episode-tongue-biting, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 9, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Episode with loss of consciousness and muscle tone that is abrupt in onset, of short duration and followed by rapid recovery; it occurs in response to transient impairment of cerebral perfusion. Typical prodromal symptoms often herald onset of syncope and postictal symptoms are minimal. Syncopal convulsions resulting from cerebral anoxia are common but are not a form of epilepsy, nor are there any accompanying EEG ictal discharges.

Fairly regular or approximately sinusoidal waves, mostly occurring in bursts at 2-3 Hz over the occipital or posterior head regions of one or both sides of the head. Frequently blocked or attenuated by opening the eyes. Comment: most commonly associated with unspecified encephalopathy, in children.

dc:description: Bursts of spike discharges at a rate from 10 to 25/sec (in most cases somewhat irregular). The bursts last more than 2 seconds (usually 2 to 10 seconds) and the runs are typically seen in sleep. Synonyms: rhythmic spikes, generalized paroxysmal fast activity, fast paroxysmal rhythms, grand mal discharge, fast beta activity.

Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 5, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S4
dc:description: A transient clearly distinguished from background activity, with pointed peak at a conventional paper speed or time scale, and duration of 70-200 ms, i.e. over 1/4-1/5 s approximately. Main component is generally negative relative to other areas. Amplitude varies.

rdfs:label: Sharp-wave-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Sharp-and-slow-wave
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 5, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S4
dc:description: A sequence of a sharp wave and a slow wave.

rdfs:label: Sharp-and-slow-wave-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Slow-sharp-wave
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 5, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S4
dc:description: A transient that bears all the characteristics of a sharp-wave, but exceeds 200 ms. Synonym: blunted sharp wave.

rdfs:label: Slow-sharp-wave-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: High-frequency-oscillation
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Wikipedia, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 5
dc:description: High Frequency Oscillation (HFO). Oscillations with a frequency higher than 80 Hz.

rdfs:label: High-frequency-oscillation-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Hypsarrhythmia-classic
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 5, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S4
dc:description: Pattern consisting of diffuse chaotic high voltage (more than 300 ??V) irregular slow waves interspersed with multiregional spikes and sharp waves over both hemispheres.

rdfs:label: Hypsarrhythmia-classic-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Hypsarrhythmia-modified
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 5, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S4
dc:description: Pattern consisting of diffuse chaotic high voltage (more than 300 ??V) irregular slow waves interspersed with multiregional spikes and sharp waves over both hemispheres.

rdfs:label: Hypsarrhythmia-modified-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Fast-spike-activity
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 12, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: A burst consisting of a sequence of spikes. Duration greater than 1 s. Frequency at least in the alpha range.

rdfs:label: Fast-spike-activity-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Low-voltage-fast-activity
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 12, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Refers to the fast, and often recruiting activity which can be recorded at the onset of an ictal discharge, particularly in invasive EEG recording of a seizure.

rdfs:label: Low-voltage-fast-activity-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Polysharp-waves
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 12, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: A sequence of two or more sharp-waves.

rdfs:label: Polysharp-waves-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Slow-wave-large-amplitude
dc:description: Slow wave of large amplitude.

rdfs:label: Slow-wave-large-amplitude-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Irregular-delta-or-theta-activity
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 12, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: EEG activity consisting of repetitive waves of inconsistent wave-duration but in delta and/or theta range (greater than 125 ms).

rdfs:label: Irregular-delta-or-theta-activity-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Electrodecremental-change
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 12, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Sudden desynchronization of electrical activity.

rdfs:label: Electrodecremental-change-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: DC-shift
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 12, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Shift of negative polarity of the direct current recordings, during seizures.

rdfs:label: DC-shift-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Disappearance-of-ongoing-activity
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 12, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Disappearance of the EEG activity that preceded the ictal event but still remnants of background activity (thus not enough to name it electrodecremental change).

rdfs:label: Disappearance-of-ongoing-activity-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: RPP-morphology
dc:description: Modifier terms for Rhythmic or Periodic Patterns in critically ill patients (RPPs).

rdfs:label: RPP-with-superimposed-activity

dc:description: Superimposed fast activity.

rdfs:label: Superimposed-fast-activity-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Superimposed-rhythmic-activity
dc:description: Superimposed rhythmic activity (for PDs only).

dc:description: Superimposed sharp waves or spikes (for RDA only).

rdfs:label: RPP-sharpness

rdfs:label: RPP-sharp

rdfs:label: RPP-sharply-contoured
dc:description: Sharply contoured.

rdfs:label: RPP-blunt
dc:description: Blunt.

rdfs:label: Number-of-RPP-phases
dc:description: Number of phases (for PDs and SW): 1, 2 or 3.

rdfs:label: Triphasic-morphology
dc:description: Waves with three distinct phases (for PDs and SW).

rdfs:label: RPP-absolute-amplitude
Attributes: suggestedTag=Property-not-possible-to-determine, suggestedTag=Low, suggestedTag=Medium, suggestedTag=High, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 8
dc:description: Absolute amplitude (for PDs, RDA, SW). Can use suggested tags for amplitude range. Very low, (Feature-amplitude, (Less-than, (Feature-amplitude/20 uv))): less than 20 microV, Low: 20 to 49 microV, Medium: 50 to 199 microV, High: Greater than 200 microV.

rdfs:label: RPP-relative-amplitude
Attributes: suggestedTag=Property-not-possible-to-determine, suggestedTag=Less-than-or-equal-to, suggestedTag=Greater-than, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 8
dc:description: Relative amplitude (for PDs), should indicate if it's less than or equal to 2 or greater than 2.

rdfs:label: RPP-polarity
Attributes: suggestedTag=Positive, suggestedTag=Negative, suggestedTag=Property-not-possible-to-determine, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 8
dc:description: Polarity (for PDs and SW).

rdfs:label: RPP-tangential-polarity
dc:description: Tangential/horizontal dipole.

rdfs:label: RPP-tangential-polarity-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Sensor-list
dc:description: Lists all corresponding sensors (electrodes/channels in montage). The sensor-group is selected from a list defined in the site-settings for each EEG-lab.

rdfs:label: Sensor-list-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Source-analysis-property
dc:description: In case source imaging is done, the results are scored at sublobar level: frontal (perisylvian-superior surface; lateral; mesial; polar; orbitofrontal), temporal (polar; basal, lateral-anterior; lateral-posterior; perisylvian-inferior surface), central (lateral convexity; mesial; central sulcus-anterior surface, central sulcus-posterior surface; opercular), parietal (lateral-convexity; mesial; opercular), occipital (lateral; mesial, basal) and insula.

rdfs:label: Source-analysis-property-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Location-property
Attributes: suggestedTag=Left, suggestedTag=Right, suggestedTag=Body-part, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Section 8 and Section 10
dc:description: Location can be scored for features. Semiologic feature can also be characterized by the somatotopic modifier (i.e. the part of the body where it occurs). In this respect, laterality (left, right, symmetric, asymmetric, left greater than right, right greater than left), body part (eyelid, face, arm, leg, trunk, visceral, left/right) and centricity (axial (trunk), proximal limb, distal limb).

rdfs:label: Feature-propagation
dc:description: When propagation within the graphoelement is observed, first the location of the onset region is scored. Then, the location of the propagation can be noted.

rdfs:label: Feature-propagation-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Multifocal-feature
dc:description: When the same interictal graphoelement is observed bilaterally and at least in three independent locations, can score them using one entry, and choosing multifocal as a descriptor of the locations of the given interictal graphoelements, optionally emphasizing the involved, and the most active sites.

rdfs:label: Multifocal-feature-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Modulators-property
dc:description: For each described graphoelement, the influence of the modulators can be scored. Only modulators present in the recording are scored.

rdfs:label: Modulators-reactivity
Attributes: suggestedTag=Modulator, suggestedTag=Feature-stopped-by, suggestedTag=Increasing, suggestedTag=Decreasing, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S2
dc:description: Susceptibility of individual rhythms or the EEG as a whole to change following sensory stimulation or other physiologic actions. The type of stimulus can be a modulator or can be specified in free-text.

rdfs:label: Modulators-reactivity-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Facilitating-factor
Attributes: suggestedTag=Catamenial, suggestedTag=Fever, suggestedTag=Intoxicated, suggestedTag=Awake, suggestedTag=Asleep, suggestedTag=Sleep-deprivation, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013
dc:description: The facilitating factors (if known) can be selected: alcohol (Suggested tag: Intoxicated), awakening, catamenial, fever, sleep, sleep-deprivation, other (free text). Facilitating factors are defined as transient and sporadic endogenous or exogenous elements capable of augmenting seizure incidence (increasing the likelihood of seizure occurrence).

rdfs:label: Other-facilitating-factor-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Provocative-factor
dc:description: Provocative factors are defined as transient and sporadic endogenous or exogenous elements capable of evoking/triggering seizures immediately following the exposure to it.

rdfs:label: Reflex-provoked-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Other-provocative-factor-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Intermittent-photic-stimulation-effect
dc:description: The effect of Intermittent Photic Stimulation (IPS) is scored according to the terminology proposed by Kasteleijn-Nolst Trenite ea (2001).

rdfs:label: Posterior-stimulus-dependent-response
Attributes: suggestedTag=Feature-frequency, annotation=dc:source Trenite ea 2001, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 7
dc:description: Anomalous steady-state VEPs, of unusually sharp waveform or high amplitude. Some types have clinical correlates, for instance, occipital spikes after suppression of generalized PPR by medication and high-amplitude VEPs in neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis.

rdfs:label: Posterior-stimulus-independent-response-limited
Attributes: suggestedTag=Feature-frequency, annotation=dc:source Trenite ea 2001, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 7
dc:description: Limited to the stimulus train: Activity confined to or maximal at the back of the head and not at the flash frequency or at a harmonic thereof. The term includes delta and theta activity and frank epileptiform patterns.

rdfs:label: Posterior-stimulus-independent-response-self-sustained
Attributes: suggestedTag=Feature-frequency, annotation=dc:source Trenite ea 2001, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 7
dc:description: Self-sustaining: Self-sustaining posterior stimulus-independent responses that outlast the stimulus train. These often last many seconds and may evolve to an overt seizure.

rdfs:label: Generalized-photoparoxysmal-response-limited
Attributes: suggestedTag=Feature-frequency, annotation=dc:source Trenite ea 2001, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 7
dc:description: Limited to the stimulus train: Comprises multiple spikes or spike-and-wave activity, which are apparently generalized, but may be of greater amplitude at the front or back of the head. It is termed a photoconvulsive response (PCR) by Bickford et al., and corresponds to type 4 response of Waltz et al.

rdfs:label: Generalized-photoparoxysmal-response-self-sustained
Attributes: suggestedTag=Feature-frequency, annotation=dc:source Trenite ea 2001, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 7
dc:description: Self-sustaining: Generalized PPR continuing after stimulation. This may not be demonstrated unless the stimulus train is terminated as soon as a generalized PPR is identified. It was termed prolonged photoconvulsive response by Reilly and Peters, and has a strong association with epilepsy and visually induced seizures in patients referred for clinical EEG examination. Its prevalence in asymptomatic general populations is unknown, but was found in five of 13,658 apparently healthy aircrew by Gregory et al.

rdfs:label: Activation-of-pre-existing-epileptogenic-area
Attributes: suggestedTag=Feature-frequency, annotation=dc:source Trenite ea 2001, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 7
dc:description: Rarely, photic stimulation may activate an epileptogenic cortex, which is also spontaneously active; IPS could then also elicit a seizure by stimulating this, usually posterior located, area. It is questionable whether this should be considered a photoparoxysmal response (PPR), and it does not figure in established classifications.

rdfs:label: Time-related-property
dc:description: Estimates of how often a graphoelement is seen in the recording.

rdfs:label: Appearance-mode
Attributes: suggestedTag=Property-not-possible-to-determine, suggestedTag=Random, suggestedTag=Repetitive, suggestedTag=Varying, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 6, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix 4.
dc:description: Describes how the non-ictal EEG pattern/graphoelement is distributed through the recording. Occurrence of the non-ictal EEG pattern / graphoelement can be Random, Repetitive or Varying. Random: occurring without any rhythmicity / periodicity, Repetitive: occurring at an approximately regular rate / interval (generally of 1 to several seconds). Variable: occurring sometimes rhythmic or periodic, other times random, throughout the recording.)

rdfs:label: Appearance-mode-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Discharge-pattern
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 6, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix 4
dc:description: Describes the organization of the EEG signal within the discharge (distinguish between single and repetitive discharges).

rdfs:label: Single-discharge
Attributes: suggestedTag=Feature-incidence, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 6, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix 4
dc:description: Applies to the intra-burst pattern: a graphoelement that is not repetitive; before and after the graphoelement one can distinguish the background activity.

rdfs:label: Rhythmic-trains-or-bursts
Attributes: suggestedTag=Feature-prevalence, suggestedTag=Feature-frequency, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 6, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix 4
dc:description: Applies to the intra-burst pattern: a non-ictal graphoelement that repeats itself without returning to the background activity between them. The graphoelements within this repetition occur at approximately constant period.

rdfs:label: Arrhythmic-trains-or-bursts
Attributes: suggestedTag=Feature-prevalence, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 6, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix 4
dc:description: Applies to the intra-burst pattern: a non-ictal graphoelement that repeats itself without returning to the background activity between them. The graphoelements within this repetition occur at inconstant period.

dc:description: Time related feature for Rhythmic or Periodic Patterns in critically ill patients (RPPs).

rdfs:label: Episode-property
dc:description: Episode property pertains to the set of characteristics that collectively depict different aspects of an episode, encompassing its manifestations and phases.

rdfs:label: Seizure-classification
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Fisher ea 2017, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017
dc:description: Seizure classification refers to the grouping of seizures based on their clinical features, EEG patterns, and other characteristics. Epileptic seizures are named using the current ILAE seizure classification.

rdfs:label: Myoclonic-seizure
Attributes: suggestedTag=Duration, annotation=dc:source Fisher ea 2017 Table 2, annotation=dc:source Duration tag from Beniczky ea Table 13
dc:description: Sudden, brief (lower than 100 msec) involuntary single or multiple contraction(s) of muscles(s) or muscle groups of variable topography (axial, proximal limb, distal). Myoclonus is less regularly repetitive and less sustained than is clonus. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version.

rdfs:label: Negative-myoclonic-seizure
dc:description: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Supplement 1, annotation=dc:source Duration tag from Beniczky ea Table 13

rdfs:label: Motor-seizure
Attributes: suggestedTag=Duration, annotation=dc:source Fisher ea 2017 Table 2, annotation=dc:source Duration tag from Beniczky ea Table 13
dc:description: Involves musculature in any form. The motor event could consist of an increase (positive) or decrease (negative) in muscle contraction to produce a movement. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version.

rdfs:label: Clonic-seizure
dc:description: Jerking, either symmetric or asymmetric, that is regularly repetitive and involves the same muscle groups. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version.

rdfs:label: Tonic-seizure
dc:description: A sustained increase in muscle contraction lasting a few seconds to minutes. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version.

rdfs:label: Atonic-seizure
dc:description: Sudden loss or diminution of muscle tone without apparent preceding myoclonic or tonic event lasting  about 1 to 2 s, involving head, trunk, jaw, or limb musculature. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version.

rdfs:label: Myoclonic-atonic-seizure
dc:description: A generalized seizure type with a myoclonic jerk leading to an atonic motor component. This type was previously called myoclonic astatic. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version.

rdfs:label: Myoclonic-tonic-clonic-seizure
dc:description: One or a few jerks of limbs bilaterally, followed by a tonic clonic seizure. The initial jerks can be considered to be either a brief period of clonus or myoclonus. Seizures with this characteristic are common in juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version.

rdfs:label: Tonic-clonic-seizure
dc:description: A sequence consisting of a tonic followed by a clonic phase. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version.

rdfs:label: Automatism-seizure
dc:description: A more or less coordinated motor activity usually occurring when cognition is impaired and for which the subject is usually (but not always) amnesic afterward. This often resembles a voluntary movement and may consist of an inappropriate continuation of preictal motor activity. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version.

rdfs:label: Epileptic-spasm
dc:description: A sudden flexion, extension, or mixed extension flexion of predominantly proximal and truncal muscles that is usually more sustained than a myoclonic movement but not as sustained as a tonic seizure. Limited forms may occur: Grimacing, head nodding, or subtle eye movements. Epileptic spasms frequently occur in clusters. Infantile spasms are the best known form, but spasms can occur at all ages. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version.

rdfs:label: Nonmotor-seizure
Attributes: suggestedTag=Duration, annotation=dc:source Fisher ea 2017 Table 2, annotation=dc:source Duration tag from Beniczky ea Table 13
dc:description: Focal or generalized seizure types in which motor activity is not prominent. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version.

rdfs:label: Behavior-arrest-seizure
dc:description: Arrest (pause) of activities, freezing, immobilization, as in behavior arrest seizure. A focal behavior arrest seizure shows arrest of behavior as the prominent feature of the entire seizure. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version.

rdfs:label: Sensory-seizure
dc:description: A perceptual experience not caused by appropriate stimuli in the external world. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version.

rdfs:label: Emotional-seizure
dc:description: Seizures presenting with an emotion or the appearance of having an emotion as an early prominent feature, such as fear, spontaneous joy or euphoria, laughing (gelastic), or crying (dacrystic). Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version.

rdfs:label: Cognitive-seizure
dc:description: Pertaining to thinking and higher cortical functions, such as language, spatial perception, memory, and praxis. The previous term for similar usage as a seizure type was psychic. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version.

rdfs:label: Autonomic-seizure
dc:description: A distinct alteration of autonomic nervous system function involving cardiovascular, pupillary, gastrointestinal, sudomotor, vasomotor, and thermoregulatory functions. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version.

rdfs:label: Absence-seizure
Attributes: suggestedTag=Duration, annotation=dc:source Fisher ea 2017 Table 2, annotation=dc:source Duration tag from Beniczky ea Table 13
dc:description: Absence seizures present with a sudden cessation of activity and awareness. Absence seizures tend to occur in younger age groups, have more sudden start and termination, and they usually display less complex automatisms than do focal seizures with impaired awareness, but the distinctions are not absolute. EEG information may be required for accurate classification. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version.

rdfs:label: Typical-absence-seizure
dc:description: A sudden onset, interruption of ongoing activities, a blank stare, possibly a brief upward deviation of the eyes. Usually the patient will be unresponsive when spoken to. Duration is a few seconds to half a minute with very rapid recovery. Although not always available, an EEG would show generalized epileptiform discharges during the event. An absence seizure is by definition a seizure of generalized onset. The word is not synonymous with a blank stare, which also can be encountered with focal onset seizures. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version.

rdfs:label: Atypical-absence-seizure
dc:description: An absence seizure with changes in tone that are more pronounced than in typical absence or the onset and/or cessation is not abrupt, often associated with slow, irregular, generalized spike-wave activity. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version.

rdfs:label: Myoclonic-absence-seizure
dc:description: A myoclonic absence seizure refers to an absence seizure with rhythmic three-per-second myoclonic movements, causing ratcheting abduction of the upper limbs leading to progressive arm elevation, and associated with three-per-second generalized spike-wave discharges. Duration is typically 10 to 60 s. Impairment of consciousness may not be obvious. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version.

rdfs:label: Eyelid-myoclonia-seizure
dc:description: Jerking of the eyelids at frequencies of at least 3 per second, commonly with upward eye deviation, usually lasting <10 s, often precipitated by eye closure. There may or may not be associated brief loss of awareness. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version.

rdfs:label: Seizure-semiology
Attributes: suggestedTag=None, suggestedTag=Duration, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Section 10, annotation=dc:source Duration tag from Beniczky ea Table 13
dc:description: Seizure semiology refers to the clinical signs and sympoms that are observed during a seizure. Semiology is described according to the ILAE Glossary of Descriptive Terminology for Ictal Semiology (Blume ea 2001). Besides the name, the semiologic feature can also be characterized by the somatotopic modifier, laterality, body part and centricity. Uses Location-property tags.

rdfs:label: Semiology-motor-behavioral-arrest
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Body-part, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Interruption of ongoing motor activity or of ongoing behaviors with fixed gaze, without movement of the head or trunk (oro-alimentary and hand automatisms may continue).

rdfs:label: Semiology-dyscognitive
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: The term describes events in which (1) disturbance of cognition is the predominant or most apparent feature, and (2a) two or more of the following components are involved, or (2b) involvement of such components remains undetermined. Otherwise, use the more specific term (e.g., mnemonic experiential seizure  or hallucinatory experiential seizure). Components of cognition: ++ perception: symbolic conception of sensory information ++ attention: appropriate selection of a principal perception or task ++ emotion: appropriate affective significance of a perception ++ memory: ability to store and retrieve percepts or concepts ++ executive function: anticipation, selection, monitoring of consequences, and initiation of motor activity including praxis, speech.

rdfs:label: Semiology-elementary-motor
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Blume ea 2001 1.1, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10
dc:description: A single type of contraction of a muscle or group of muscles that is usually stereotyped and not decomposable into phases. However, see tonic-clonic, an elementary motor sequence.

rdfs:label: Semiology-myoclonic-jerk
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Body-part, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Characterized by myoclonus. MYOCLONUS : sudden, brief (lower than 100 ms) involuntary single or multiple contraction(s) of muscles(s) or muscle groups of variable topography (axial, proximal limb, distal).

rdfs:label: Semiology-negative-myoclonus
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Body-part, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Characterized by negative myoclonus. NEGATIVE MYOCLONUS: interruption of tonic muscular activity for lower than 500 ms without evidence of preceding myoclonia.

rdfs:label: Semiology-clonic
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Body-part, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Myoclonus that is regularly repetitive, involves the same muscle groups, at a frequency of about 2 to 3 c/s, and is prolonged. Synonym: rhythmic myoclonus.

rdfs:label: Semiology-jacksonian-march
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Body-part, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Term indicating spread of clonic movements through contiguous body parts unilaterally.

rdfs:label: Semiology-epileptic-spasm
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Body-part, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: A sudden flexion, extension, or mixed extension flexion of predominantly proximal and truncal muscles that is usually more sustained than a myoclonic movement but not so sustained as a tonic seizure (i.e., about 1 s). Limited forms may occur: grimacing, head nodding. Frequent occurrence in clusters.

rdfs:label: Semiology-tonic
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Body-part, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: A sustained increase in muscle contraction lasting a few seconds to minutes.

rdfs:label: Semiology-dystonic
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Body-part, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Sustained contractions of both agonist and antagonist muscles producing athetoid or twisting movements, which, when prolonged, may produce abnormal postures.

rdfs:label: Semiology-postural
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Body-part, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Adoption of a posture that may be bilaterally symmetric or asymmetric (as in a fencing posture).

rdfs:label: Semiology-versive
Attributes: suggestedTag=Body-part, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: A sustained, forced conjugate ocular, cephalic, and/or truncal rotation or lateral deviation from the midline.

rdfs:label: Semiology-tonic-clonic
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Body-part, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: A sequence consisting of a tonic followed by a clonic phase. Variants such as clonic-tonic-clonic may be seen.

rdfs:label: Semiology-tonic-clonic-without-figure-of-four
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Without figure of four: Asymmetry of limb posture during the tonic phase of a GTC: one arm is rigidly extended at the elbow (often with the fist clenched tightly and flexed at the wrist), whereas the opposite arm is flexed at the elbow.

rdfs:label: Semiology-tonic-clonic-with-figure-of-four-extension-left-elbow
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: With figure of four: Asymmetry of limb posture during the tonic phase of a GTC: one arm is rigidly extended at the elbow (often with the fist clenched tightly and flexed at the wrist), whereas the opposite arm is flexed at the elbow.

rdfs:label: Semiology-tonic-clonic-with-figure-of-four-extension-right-elbow
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: With figure of four: Asymmetry of limb posture during the tonic phase of a GTC: one arm is rigidly extended at the elbow (often with the fist clenched tightly and flexed at the wrist), whereas the opposite arm is flexed at the elbow.

rdfs:label: Semiology-astatic
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Body-part, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Loss of erect posture that results from an atonic, myoclonic, or tonic mechanism. Synonym: drop attack.

rdfs:label: Semiology-atonic
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Body-part, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Sudden loss or diminution of muscle tone without apparent preceding myoclonic or tonic event lasting greater or equal to 1 to 2 s, involving head, trunk, jaw, or limb musculature.

rdfs:label: Semiology-subtle-motor-phenomena
Attributes: requireChild, suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10

rdfs:label: Semiology-subtle-motor-phenomena-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Semiology-other-elementary-motor-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Semiology-automatisms
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Fisher ea 2017 Table 2
dc:description: A more or less coordinated, repetitive, motor activity usually occurring when cognition is impaired and for which the subject is usually amnesic afterward. This often resembles a voluntary movement and may consist of an inappropriate continuation of ongoing preictal motor activity.

rdfs:label: Semiology-mimetic
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Facial expression suggesting an emotional state, often fear.

rdfs:label: Semiology-oroalimentary
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Lip smacking, lip pursing, chewing, licking, tooth grinding, or swallowing.

rdfs:label: Semiology-dacrystic
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Bursts of crying.

rdfs:label: Semiology-manual
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source  Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: 1. Indicates principally distal components, bilateral or unilateral. 2. Fumbling, tapping, manipulating movements.

rdfs:label: Semiology-gestural
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Semipurposive, asynchronous hand movements. Often unilateral.

rdfs:label: Semiology-hypermotor
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Body-part, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: 1. Involves predominantly proximal limb or axial muscles producing irregular sequential ballistic movements, such as pedaling, pelvic thrusting, thrashing, rocking movements. 2. Increase in rate of ongoing movements or inappropriately rapid performance of a movement.

rdfs:label: Semiology-hypokinetic
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Body-part, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: A decrease in amplitude and/or rate or arrest of ongoing motor activity.

rdfs:label: Semiology-gelastic
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Bursts of laughter or giggling, usually without an appropriate affective tone.

rdfs:label: Semiology-other-automatisms-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Semiology-sensory
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Blume ea 2001 2.2
dc:description: A perceptual experience not caused by appropriate stimuli in the external world. Modifies seizure or aura.

rdfs:label: Semiology-headache
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Headache occurring in close temporal proximity to the seizure or as the sole seizure manifestation.

rdfs:label: Semiology-visual
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Flashing or flickering lights, spots, simple patterns, scotomata, or amaurosis.

rdfs:label: Semiology-auditory
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Buzzing, drumming sounds or single tones.

rdfs:label: Semiology-gustatory
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Taste sensations including acidic, bitter, salty, sweet, or metallic.

rdfs:label: Semiology-epigastric
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Abdominal discomfort including nausea, emptiness, tightness, churning, butterflies, malaise, pain, and hunger; sensation may rise to chest or throat. Some phenomena may reflect ictal autonomic dysfunction.

rdfs:label: Semiology-somatosensory
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Body-part, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Tingling, numbness, electric-shock sensation, sense of movement or desire to move.

rdfs:label: Semiology-autonomic-sensation
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5, annotation=dc:source Blume ea 2001 2.2.1.8
dc:description: Viscerosensitive. A sensation consistent with involvement of the autonomic nervous system, including cardiovascular, gastrointestinal,  sudomotor, vasomotor, and thermoregulatory functions. (Thus autonomic aura; cf. autonomic events 3.0/Semiology-autonomic).

rdfs:label: Semiology-sensory-other-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Semiology-experiential
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Blume ea 2001 2.2.2
dc:description: Affective, mnemonic, or composite perceptual phenomena including illusory or composite hallucinatory events; these may appear alone or in combination. Included are feelings of depersonalization. These phenomena have subjective qualities similar to those experienced in life but are recognized by the subject as occurring outside of actual context.

rdfs:label: Semiology-affective-emotional
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Components include fear, depression, joy, and (rarely) anger.

rdfs:label: Semiology-hallucinatory
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Composite perceptions without corresponding external stimuli involving visual, auditory, somatosensory, olfactory, and/or gustatory phenomena. Example: hearing  and seeing  people talking.

rdfs:label: Semiology-illusory
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: An alteration of actual percepts involving the visual, auditory, somatosensory, olfactory, or gustatory systems.

rdfs:label: Semiology-mnemonic
Attributes: suggestedTag=Familiar, suggestedTag=Unfamiliar, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Components that reflect ictal dysmnesia such as feelings of familiarity (deja-vu) and unfamiliarity (jamais-vu). Use suggested tags to indicate Familiar (deja-vu) or Unfamiliar (jamais-vu).

rdfs:label: Semiology-experiential-other-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Semiology-vocalization
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Single or repetitive utterances consisting of sounds such as grunts or shrieks.

rdfs:label: Semiology-verbalization
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Single or repetitive utterances consisting of words, phrases, or brief sentences.

rdfs:label: Semiology-dysphasia
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Partially impaired communication involving language without dysfunction of relevant primary motor or sensory pathways, manifested as impaired comprehension, anomia, paraphasic errors, or a combination of these. (

rdfs:label: Semiology-aphasia
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Fully impaired communication involving language without dysfunction of relevant primary motor or sensory pathways, manifested as impaired comprehension, anomia, paraphasic errors, or a combination of these.

rdfs:label: Semiology-language-other-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Semiology-autonomic
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Blume ea 2001 3.2
dc:description: An objectively documented and distinct alteration of autonomic nervous system function involving cardiovascular, pupillary, gastrointestinal, sudomotor, vasomotor, and thermoregularity functions (cf. Semiology-autonomic-sensation).

rdfs:label: Semiology-pupillary
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Mydriasis, miosis (either bilateral or unilateral).

rdfs:label: Semiology-hypersalivation
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Increase in production of saliva leading to uncontrollable drooling.

rdfs:label: Semiology-respiratory-apnoeic
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Subjective shortness of breath, hyperventilation, stridor, coughing, choking, apnea, oxygen desaturation, neurogenic pulmonary edema.

rdfs:label: Semiology-cardiovascular
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Modifications of heart rate (tachycardia, bradycardia), cardiac arrhythmias (such as sinus arrhythmia, sinus arrest, supraventricular tachycardia, atrial premature depolarizations, ventricular premature depolarizations, atrio-ventricular block, bundle branch block, atrioventricular nodal escape rhythm, asystole).

rdfs:label: Semiology-gastrointestinal
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Nausea, eructation, vomiting, retching, abdominal sensations, abdominal pain, flatulence, spitting, diarrhea.

rdfs:label: Semiology-urinary-incontinence
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Urinary urge (intense urinary urge at the beginning of seizures), urinary incontinence, ictal urination (rare symptom of partial seizures without loss of consciousness).

rdfs:label: Semiology-genital
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Sexual auras (erotic thoughts and feelings, sexual arousal and orgasm). Genital auras (unpleasant, sometimes painful, frightening or emotionally neutral somatosensory sensations in the genitals that can be accompanied by ictal orgasm). Sexual automatisms (hypermotor movements consisting of writhing, thrusting, rhythmic movements of the pelvis, arms and legs, sometimes associated with picking and rhythmic manipulation of the groin or genitalia, exhibitionism and masturbation).

rdfs:label: Semiology-vasomotor
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Flushing or pallor (may be accompanied by feelings of warmth, cold and pain).

rdfs:label: Semiology-sudomotor
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 10, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Sweating and piloerection (may be accompanied by feelings of warmth, cold and pain).

rdfs:label: Semiology-thermoregulatory
dc:description: Hyperthermia, fever. (Source: Beniczky ea 2017, Table 10; Beniczky ea 2013, Appendix S5.)

rdfs:label: Semiology-autonomic-other-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Semiology-manifestation-other-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Postictal-semiology
Attributes: suggestedTag=None, suggestedTag=Duration, annotation=dc:source Blume ea 2001, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 11, annotation=dc:source Duration tag from Beniczky ea Table 13
dc:description: A transient clinical abnormality of central nervous system function that appears or becomes accentuated when clinical signs of the ictus have ended.

rdfs:label: Postictal-unconscious
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 11, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Unawareness and unresponsiveness.

rdfs:label: Postictal-quick-recovery-of-consciousness
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 11, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Quick recovery of awareness and responsiveness. )

rdfs:label: Postictal-aphasia-or-dysphasia
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 11, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Impaired communication involving language without dysfunction of relevant primary motor or sensory pathways, manifested as impaired comprehension, anomia, parahasic errors or a combination of these.

rdfs:label: Postictal-behavioral-change
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 11, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Occurring immediately after a seizure. Including psychosis, hypomanina, obsessive-compulsive behavior.

rdfs:label: Postictal-hemianopia
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 11, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Postictal visual loss in a a hemi field.

rdfs:label: Postictal-impaired-cognition
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 11, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Decreased Cognitive performance involving one or more of perception, attention, emotion, memory, execution, praxis, speech.

rdfs:label: Postictal-dysphoria
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 11, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Depression, irritability, euphoric mood, fear, anxiety.

rdfs:label: Postictal-headache
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 11, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Headache with features of tension-type or migraine headache that develops within 3 h following the seizure and resolves within 72 h after seizure.

rdfs:label: Postictal-nose-wiping
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 11, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Noes-wiping usually within 60 sec of seizure offset, usually with the hand ipsilateral to the seizure onset.

rdfs:label: Postictal-anterograde-amnesia
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 11, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Impaired ability to remember new material.

rdfs:label: Postictal-retrograde-amnesia
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 11, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Impaired ability to recall previously remember material.

rdfs:label: Postictal-paresis
Attributes: suggestedTag=Categorical-location-value, suggestedTag=Body-part, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 11, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Todds palsy. Any unilateral postictal dysfunction relating to motor, language, sensory and/or integrative functions.

rdfs:label: Postictal-sleep
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 11, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Invincible need to sleep after a seizure.

rdfs:label: Postictal-unilateral-myoclonic-jerks
Attributes: annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 11, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Unilateral myoclonic jerks. Myoclonus: sudden, brief (<100 ms) involuntary single or multiple contraction(s) of muscles(s) or muscle groups of variable topography (axial, proximal limb, distal).

rdfs:label: Postictal-other-unilateral-motor-phenomena
Attributes: requireChild, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 11, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2013 Appendix S5
dc:description: Unilateral motor phenomena, other then specified above, occurring in the postictal phase.

rdfs:label: Postictal-other-unilateral-motor-phenomena-#
dc:description: Free text.

rdfs:label: Episode-time-context-property
dc:description: Additional clinically relevant features related to episodes can be scored under timing and context. If needed, episode duration can be tagged with suggested tag.

rdfs:label: Episode-consciousness-affected
Attributes: suggestedTag=False, suggestedTag=Some, suggestedTag=True, suggestedTag=Property-not-possible-to-determine, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 13

rdfs:label: Episode-awareness
Attributes: suggestedTag=True, suggestedTag=False, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 13
dc:description: False: the patient is not aware of the episode. True: the patient is aware of the episode.

rdfs:label: Episode-event-count
dc:description: Number of stereotypical episodes during the recording.

rdfs:label: Status-epilepticus
dc:description: Episode with duration >30 min but not precisely determined (status epilepticus).

rdfs:label: Episode-prodrome
Attributes: suggestedTag=True, suggestedTag=False, annotation=dc:source Blume ea 2001, annotation=dc:source Beniczky ea 2017 Table 13
dc:description: Prodrome is a preictal phenomenon, and it is defined as a subjective or objective clinical alteration (e.g., ill-localized sensation or agitation) that heralds the onset of an epileptic seizure but does not form part of it (Blume ea 2001). Therefore, prodrome should be distinguished from aura (which is an ictal phenomenon). If prodrome present/true + free text.

dc:description: It is important to score the significance of the described artifacts: recording is not interpretable, recording of reduced diagnostic value, does not interfere with the interpretation of the recording.

dc:description: Not possible to determine.
